speaker: All
text_entry: SCENE VI. Antium. A public place.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS, with Attendants

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Go tell the lords o' the city I am here:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Deliver them this paper: having read it,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Bid them repair to the market place; where I,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Even in theirs and in the commons' ears,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Will vouch the truth of it. Him I accuse

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The city ports by this hath enter'd and

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Intends to appear before the people, hoping

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To purge herself with words: dispatch.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt Attendants

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Enter three or four Conspirators of AUFIDIUS' faction

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Most welcome!

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: How is it with our general?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Even so

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As with a man by his own alms empoison'd,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And with his charity slain.

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: Most noble sir,

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: If you do hold the same intent wherein

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: You wish'd us parties, we'll deliver you

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: Of your great danger.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Sir, I cannot tell:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We must proceed as we do find the people.

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: The people will remain uncertain whilst

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: 'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: Makes the survivor heir of all.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I know it;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And my pretext to strike at him admits

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: A good construction. I raised him, and I pawn'd

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Mine honour for his truth: who being so heighten'd,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He water'd his new plants with dews of flattery,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Seducing so my friends; and, to this end,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He bow'd his nature, never known before

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: But to be rough, unswayable and free.

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: Sir, his stoutness

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: When he did stand for consul, which he lost

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: By lack of stooping,--

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: That I would have spoke of:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Presented to my knife his throat: I took him;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: In all his own desires; nay, let him choose

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Out of my files, his projects to accomplish,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My best and freshest men; served his designments

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: In mine own person; holp to reap the fame

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which he did end all his; and took some pride

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To do myself this wrong: till, at the last,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I seem'd his follower, not partner, and

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He waged me with his countenance, as if

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I had been mercenary.

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: So he did, my lord:

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: The army marvell'd at it, and, in the last,

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: When he had carried Rome and that we look'd

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: For no less spoil than glory,--

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: There was it:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: At a few drops of women's rheum, which are

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Of our great action: therefore shall he die,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And I'll renew me in his fall. But, hark!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Drums and trumpets sound, with great shouts of the People

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: Your native town you enter'd like a post,

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: And had no welcomes home: but he returns,

speaker: First Conspirator
text_entry: Splitting the air with noise.

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: And patient fools,

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear

speaker: Second Conspirator
text_entry: With giving him glory.

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: Therefore, at your vantage,

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: Ere he express himself, or move the people

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: With what he would say, let him feel your sword,

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: Which we will second. When he lies along,

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: After your way his tale pronounced shall bury

speaker: Third Conspirator
text_entry: His reasons with his body.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Say no more:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Here come the lords.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Enter the Lords of the city

speaker: All The Lords
text_entry: You are most welcome home.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I have not deserved it.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: What I have written to you?

speaker: Lords
text_entry: We have.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And grieve to hear't.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: What faults he made before the last, I think

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Might have found easy fines: but there to end

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Where he was to begin and give away

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The benefit of our levies, answering us

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: With our own charge, making a treaty where

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: There was a yielding,--this admits no excuse.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He approaches: you shall hear him.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS, marching with drum and colours; commoners being with him

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No more infected with my country's love

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Under your great command. You are to know

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That prosperously I have attempted and

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With bloody passage led your wars even to

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The gates of Rome. Our spoils we have brought home

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Do more than counterpoise a full third part

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The charges of the action. We have made peace

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With no less honour to the Antiates

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than shame to the Romans: and we here deliver,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Subscribed by the consuls and patricians,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Together with the seal o' the senate, what

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: We have compounded on.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Read it not, noble lords;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: But tell the traitor, in the high'st degree

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He hath abused your powers.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Traitor! how now!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Ay, traitor, Marcius!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Marcius!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius: dost thou think

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n name

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Coriolanus in Corioli?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: You lords and heads o' the state, perfidiously

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He has betray'd your business, and given up,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: For certain drops of salt, your city Rome,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I say 'your city,' to his wife and mother;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Breaking his oath and resolution like

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: A twist of rotten silk, never admitting

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Counsel o' the war, but at his nurse's tears

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: He whined and roar'd away your victory,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: That pages blush'd at him and men of heart

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Look'd wondering each at other.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hear'st thou, Mars?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Name not the god, thou boy of tears!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: No more.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Too great for what contains it. Boy! O slave!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I was forced to scold. Your judgments, my grave lords,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion--

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him; that

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Must bear my beating to his grave--shall join

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To thrust the lie unto him.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Peace, both, and hear me speak.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Stain all your edges on me. Boy! false hound!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If you have writ your annals true, 'tis there,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Alone I did it. Boy!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Why, noble lords,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: 'Fore your own eyes and ears?

speaker: All Conspirators
text_entry: Let him die for't.

speaker: All The People
text_entry: 'Tear him to pieces.' 'Do it presently.' 'He kill'd

speaker: All The People
text_entry: my son.' 'My daughter.' 'He killed my cousin

speaker: All The People
text_entry: Marcus.' 'He killed my father.'

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Peace, ho! no outrage: peace!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: The man is noble and his fame folds-in

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This orb o' the earth. His last offences to us

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And trouble not the peace.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O that I had him,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To use my lawful sword!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Insolent villain!

speaker: All Conspirators
text_entry: Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!

speaker: All Conspirators
text_entry: The Conspirators draw, and kill CORIOLANUS: AUFIDIUS stands on his body

speaker: Lords
text_entry: Hold, hold, hold, hold!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My noble masters, hear me speak.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: O Tullus,--

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: Tread not upon him. Masters all, be quiet;

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: Put up your swords.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My lords, when you shall know--as in this rage,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Provoked by him, you cannot--the great danger

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which this man's life did owe you, you'll rejoice

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: That he is thus cut off. Please it your honours

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To call me to your senate, I'll deliver

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Myself your loyal servant, or endure

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Your heaviest censure.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Bear from hence his body;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And mourn you for him: let him be regarded

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: As the most noble corse that ever herald

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Did follow to his urn.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: His own impatience

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let's make the best of it.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My rage is gone;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And I am struck with sorrow. Take him up.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Help, three o' the chiefest soldiers; I'll be one.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournfully:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Hath widow'd and unchilded many a one,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which to this hour bewail the injury,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Yet he shall have a noble memory. Assist.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt, bearing the body of CORIOLANUS. A dead march sounded
